asgn1Question

Interface Log


  • public interface Log

    A log is a series of values, recording how some quantifiable property has changed over time. Although such a series could conceivably grow without bound, here we require only a fixed "window" of recent entries to be kept (which allows us to implement the Log class in a space-efficient way). The size of the window must be at least one for the log to be useful.

    The characteristic feature of the Log type is that entries in the series are indexed in reverse, using non-positive values, in accordance with the notion that the type implements a log of past values. Thus the most recent entry is at index 0, the previous entry is at index −1, etc. For a log with window size N the oldest entry stored is at index −N + 1.

    Conceptually we could create a generic Log class capable of storing values of different types. However, for simplicity, we assume here that log entries are always natural numbers, represented by non-negative Integers.

    Your first two tasks in the assignment are to implement this interface as class WaterLog, and to produce a comprehensive unit test suite for it.

    Constructor:
    To connect to the provided GUI, your WaterLog class must provide a constructor with the following signature, as well as all the methods below. (Observation: We've expressed this requirement as a comment because it isn't possible to define a constructor in an interface.)
    Parameters:
    Integer windowSize - the (minimum) number of entries that the log must retain
    Integer maxEntry - the largest value that will ever be entered in the log
    Throws:
    SimulationException - if windowSize is not strictly positive (i.e., greater than zero)
    SimulationException - if maxEntry is negative (i.e., less than zero)

    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    INB370

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void addEntry(java.lang.Integer newEntry)
      Adds a new entry to the log.
      java.lang.Integer getEntry(java.lang.Integer index)
      Returns the log entry at the given index.
      java.lang.Integer numEntries()
      Returns the total number of log entries that have been made since the log was constructed.
      java.lang.Integer variation()
      Returns the numerical difference between the most recent and oldest entries in the log.

    • Method Detail

      • addEntry

        void addEntry(java.lang.Integer newEntry)
              throws SimulationException
        Adds a new entry to the log. Existing entries are shifted along one place in the window accordingly.
        Parameters:
        newEntry - the new value to be added to the log
        Throws:
        SimulationException - if the given value is not in the range 0 to maxEntry, inclusive

      • getEntry

        java.lang.Integer getEntry(java.lang.Integer index)
                           throws SimulationException
        Returns the log entry at the given index. For a log with window size N, index 0 is the most recently added entry and index −N + 1 is the oldest. If there is no log entry at the given index, because too few entries have been made to the log so far, null is returned. Since this is not a valid log entry it alerts the caller to the fact that the requested entry does not exist.
        Parameters:
        index - the index of the required entry
        Returns:
        the log entry at the specified position or null if there is no such entry
        Throws:
        SimulationException - if the given index is not in the valid range of indices for a log with this window size (i.e., not between −N + 1 and 0, inclusive, for a window of size N)

      • variation

        java.lang.Integer variation()
                            throws SimulationException
        Returns the numerical difference between the most recent and oldest entries in the log. This value will be positive if the most recent entry is larger than the oldest (indicating that the measured quantity has increased), negative if the most recent entry is less than the oldest (indicating that the measured quantity has decreased) or zero if they are the same (indicating no overall change in the quantity of interest). Note that the "oldest" entry in the log will be the first entry made if the total number of entries to date is equal to or less than the window size N. Otherwise, it is the entry at index −N + 1.
        Returns:
        the numerical difference between the most recent and oldest entries retained in the log's fixed-size window
        Throws:
        SimulationException - if there are no entries in the log

      • numEntries

        java.lang.Integer numEntries()
        Returns the total number of log entries that have been made since the log was constructed. (NB: The total number of such entries may be greater than the "window" size.)
        Returns:
        the number of log entries made so far
